children.subject:
In terms of large tech companies (e.g FB, Google, Amazon, Microsoft), getting an internship is much easier than getting a full-time offer, both in terms of number of interviews and the difficulty of questions asked. If you have a good grasp of 61A, 61B, and 170, getting an internship at these companies should be doable (getting an interview there is the hard part).

To see the types of questions asked at these companies, check out and do a bunch of problems on Leetcode.

This obviously isn't a viable or desirable option for everyone, but have you looked into possibly staying an extra year to finish the CS major? You would be allowed to do it if you were a double major; the college of L&S lets you stay for 5 years to finish a second major.

In my experience, getting an internship is much easier than getting a full-time position. Not only are the interview questions easier for internships (think 61A/B + 70 level for internships vs 170 + any applicable UDs level for full-time), once you get an internship and you perform well, you'll have a chance to get a return offer - maybe even without an interview for the full-time position since the company will have known you by then.

Internship is easier than full time. Just note that some companies will restrict you from applying to internships as a Senior. Also if you do get an internship offer, let your recruiter know that you intend to convert at the end of your internship. Obviously this will be dependent on your performance, but you’ll know before hand if it’s possible or not.

Although I haven’t taken it myself, CS 169 looks useful for those who haven’t done a typical software internship.

history.content:
Hi,

Unlike most of you, I'm actually a senior, econ major, who just decided to commit myself to cs. I have taken /struggled through 61a, 61b, 70, and will be taking 170 in the upcoming semester while recruiting. My best option is to get a full time directly, but I'm willing to take an internship position first and then convert it if I need to.

I'm not sure how much more difficult it is to get a full-time offer than an internship offer. Can people share their experiences? How many interview questions for both recruitments, and how much harder full time interview questions are? Are there particular topics that are more favored by full time than internship? 

Thank you so much :)
history.subject: Internship vs. Full Time Difficulty
